A nice gift shop with prices for everyone and a cafe connected to the museum. Friday evening from 5-9pm price is $1/person. Plenty of parking nearby and a garage across the street. Children's Museum Boston is the place to be!

My girlfriend and I were babysitting a 4 year old and decided to take her to the Children's Museum since they have an exhibit on dinosaurs and she currently loves dinos. She had a fun time climbing up and down the "jungle gym" that greets you in the lobby as well as checking out the dinos, climbing around in the construction zone and checking out all of the other exhibits.

You can easily spend an afternoon here and get the kids tired out. There is so much to see and do for kids and some great moments for parents to bond with their children.

Our sons are 5 and 8 and they absolutely loved this museum! What was especially great is that all the exhibits were very hands on, and so, really fantastic for kids in that mid age range. They especially loved the science area, and the door to ceiling climbing install was amazing! The adults found the Japanese house particularly worth the visit, the the kids also enjoyed it and asked a ton of questions that the knowledgeable attendant was more than happy to answer! It's also great that they offered free admission to active teachers. We will definitely be back!
There are many interesting exhibits with a hands on approach to learning. The museum is busy much of the time, so keep a close eye, especially on younger children.

Do go with yours kids. Lots of places inside to explore, drive a mock plane, a tent, science place, climbing, bubble place (and the live turtle near it), etc. Do take own food as it will help after kids jump and run around! It's one of the small Disney with kids in best spirits around! (it's $1 entry after 5pm till 9pm on Fri)

A treasure in the city. Watch for discount passes, use your library museum pass etc.  Go early to find street parking on a weekend otherwise garage is around the corner and is validated in museum. Special programs always available. Don't try to do it all in one visit or you and your kids will be miserable.
My family and I loved it here definitely recommend this place if you have children it has heaps of fun this for them to do you can join in on the fun too

Although pricey, the Museum is wonderful and so much fun! The only negative experience was the scam at Farnsworth Garage, which the museum provides parking validation for. The cost is supposed to be $25 but the garage charged us $38 and the attendant there claimed our validation was no good. The attendant offered no solution for us and was extremely rude. We quickly let the Museum know of this issue and they were very attentive about it. I advise avoiding this parking garage but if you must park here and run into an issue make sure to let the Museum know. Here is the number for the manager at the garage, Duvante: 857-237-8756

Spent the day at the Boston Children’s museum. There is a lot of hands exhibits for kids to interact with.
We went on a Monday holiday and the place was packed. Next time I would not go on a holiday.
They have a nice gift shop, but felt like it was geared for younger children.
Make sure to see if your library offers museum passes, it will save you some money.
Our 3.5 yo son loved it. Suitable probably even more for slightly older children. Quite expensive though given it’s basically a giant indoor (albeit fun) playground for kids.

So much to do  all sorts of room s for make believe  
Climbing —dancing —barber shop —car repair —school room  
a snake ——
And there are people complaining there isn’t much to do—-
Those are the people who will not like heaven !!!!!!
Little kids playing with water 💧 
Etc 
look at the website look what is available
And pick a few to visit 
It s great. It is not the Taj Mahal or an arcade it is for young children 
Lol😂🤣😄😃😀

name: Old North Church & Historic Site
reviews: The Bell Tower Tour is a great addition to a visit to the Old North Church, the church from which the "two if by sea" lanterns made famous by Henry Longfellow Wadsworth's poem "The Midnight Ride of Paul Revere." In addition to admission to the church which includes an informative presentation by a docent, you also get to climb the stairs to the bell tower. Be warned - the steps are steep and there's curve, but it's manageable unless you really are not able to climb stairs normally. Unfortunately, the stairs are not original to the church, and the minister who hung the lanterns from the bell tower that fateful night climbed a series of internal ladders that no longer exist, but the area you visit on the tour is the area from which the bells are still rung.  Additionally, the tour takes you underground, into the original crypt and  the docent provides intriguing details about its inhabitants.
This church Is  preserved beautifully,  I loved seeing the pew boxes and reading the names, there is a wonderful gift shop as well and they let you explore at your own pace, everyone was friendly.

While the Freedom Trail offers a great overview of early colonial/ revolutionary war history, the North church provides the spiritual sense of the entire endeavor, as well as an appreciation for the sacrifice and risk these men dealt with. This is in my opinion the one absolute thing on the trail not to be missed. Be sure to listen to the talks which are given while sitting in the pews. Helps to understand the history.

This was really an amazing experience.  I am very into history, so I found seeing where the lanterns were placed to warn the riders to warn the militia the regulars, not the British, were coming by sea.  This eventually led to the fighting at Lexington and Concord.  Paul Revere contributed, but there were other riders who deserve credit.  The church was also very nice and was on the Freedom Trail.
The staff was very informative- beautiful old church. Lots of stories surrounding the church of you take the time to listen to the staff. Glad we stopped!
This is a small historic place to visit during your stay in Boston to know more about the story and smell their peacefulness.
This church is stunning and so historical, just wandered about taking in its beauty. Definitely worth a visit

We loved the Behind the Scenes tour. The church is very unique. The staff members were friendly and helpful. My 10 year old son thought it was cool to see the crypt, bell ringing chamber and colonial chocolate demonstration.

name: HarborWalk
reviews: Easy walk along the river that anyone can do. Area Residents jog or walk their pets. Very peaceful and away from the hustle and bustle.

The HarborWalk is not at all obvious as a pedestrian attraction, but it does indeed provide some of the best views of Boston as it winds its way around. 

The full walk as listed on their map is far larger than most people will be interested in walking, but the best part is the section that starts on the eastern edge of the North End, works its way around Boston Harbor past Quincy Market and the New England Aquarium, goes right through the tour boats and nice restaurants around Rowe's Wharf, and finally crosses the Fort Point channel over to the Federal Courthouse where you will get the most amazing views of Boston.

The HarborWalk isn't really anything more than a wide, paved pedestrian walkway that follows the edge of Boston Harbor.  It doesn't have any specific shops or restaurants and in some places you will be walking through mainly residential areas.

The entire pathway is paved and clear enough for a child to ride a bicycle along the path as well.

Followed the Freedom trail here and got the opportunity to to see plenty of historical museums and areas.  The USS Constitution is berthed here and several areas managed by the National Park Service.  Take the time to visit here, you won't regret it!
We took the opportunity to walk a fair section of the Harbour Walk whilst staying in Boston and felt it gave us a good impression of both old and new Boston as well as some of the history.

Our tour guide told us about the walk, and at the time, we were stunned by how long it is. We decided to try and see how long we could walk it for, and found that a couple of hours was enough for us. The view is spectacular, it's a nice, relaxing walk, and it's definitely worth a shot.

name: Castle Island
address: 2010 William J Day Blvd end of Carson Beach, on Pleasure Bay
reviews: This is a fantastic place to take a stroll and watch the planes land at Logan, grab a quick bite at Sullivan's and watch the boats in Boston Harbor, or just people watch.  The walk around the perimeter of Castle Island (just over 2 miles) is a nice stretch of the legs.  There is also a nice playground for the kids to burn off some energy, and when Fort Independence is open, you can take a tour.

Wanted to be on the water today but didn’t have the time to go down to the Cape. This was a great afternoon, packed a lunch, walked around took in the sights. Very accessible and plenty of parking. Perfect for place to watch the planes takeoff and land for any airplane fans.

Although parking can be crowded, you can always get a spot. People are coming and going at all times.
There are so many things to see and do. Not to mention eating at Sullivan’s - their hot dogs are well know. 

Activities include: watching airplanes fly right over your head into Logan airport, Boston., walking paths, biking, skate boarding, watching boats in/out of Boston harbor, tour of the castle, or just people watching.

Great outdoor place for young and old!
Don't forget to sight see this area, it is truly a gem!  Don't forget to take a drive up to the L St. Tavern for a pint, the scene from Good Will Hunting movie!

This was the first time I had ever been to the ocean and it was definitely the place to go.  Calm water, serene atmosphere, beautiful castle. The weather was a little cold though, but still incredible!!!!!
I am a water baby and decided to go for the day.  Imagine my surprise when I see two juvenile eagles.  I waited long enough to see at least one parent.  I'll definitely be back.
We enjoyed walking in the area and watching the boats. There is a small restaurant you can walk to but it is only outdoor seating. Good food and reasonable prices.

Wonderful view of the many islands in Boston Harbor. Great place to watch planes land at Logan Airport. The fort dates back to the original fort (1634) know as “The Castle.” A lot of history attached to this site - of course, it IS Boston! Great walk around the fort itself. Lots of activities - a small beach, sailing, picnicking, playground. Can also grab something to eat st Sullivan’s. Long lines on Sunday afternoon when we were there. Great spot! Worth a visit.

name: Skywalk Observatory
reviews: As far as I know, this is the highest publicly-accessible observation deck in Boston. It provides great views of the city. The are a lot of informative materials. The staff is friendly. The deck isn’t crowded. Even though the deck’s lights are dimmed after sunset, it’s not easy to take photos due to reflections, but it’s an issue for most of the observation decks, not just this one. If you have troubles taking photos, just watch, enjoy and remember :)

Great views 360 degrees around the whole tower, lots of educational displays and short movies about history of boston, etc. It’s all indoor, which makes it nice year-round, but for me to give the 5th star it would need the addition of an outdoor section (even if it was a small one) to get the full raw experience of being up that high and fully soaking in the city view. Good activity for an hour or two, worth it.

Loved our visit here, definitely worth the entrance fee. The staff were very friendly and helpful and the audio device you carry around explains both the history and views as you look out over the city and surrounding areas. We had a beautiful sunny morning when we visited so could really see for miles. My daughter asked if she could use her UK student card for discount and this was easily accepted. Lots of information on how Boston was built with immigrants from all over the world, and continues this tradition now. Very poignant in today's climate.
Sadly the skywalk will soon be closed but the views up top were amazing and we received top notch service form the staff!

I don’t think this would have been on our radar if it hadn’t been for the CityPass. I went about an hour before sunset on a weekday and it was quite quiet and so we got some good views. Simple concept. The included audio guide is essential to get any real value out of the visit. However I would have liked some more skyline pictures or staff to point out things to help pick out key buildings to have made this a five star.

name: Bunker Hill Monument
reviews: I recommend starting at the beginning of the Freedom Trail and working your way here. While Bunker Hill is great by itself, it gives one a better understanding and appreciation of all the parts that led to this battle on Breed's Hill (yes, I said Breed's). Stop by the museum across the street first to explore and get tickets to climb the stairs up the middle of the monument. It's free but usually requires tickets. The monument is great from the outside and inside. Inside at the top gives you a great perspective of the surrounding area. Even today you can see how prominent the Old North Church is and why it was used as a beacon in 1775. By the way, if you're not keen on climbing stairs or heights, the trip is still worth it.
Right on the Freedom trail you can climb the 294 steps to the top of this monument and get a great view of Boston.

My husband and I stopped here towards the end of our Freedom Trail tour. We did the tour on our own finding information from the Freedom Trail website. It is thorough and informative and allowed us to skip purchasing a tour for the day! 

Bunker Hill was the first major battle in the Revolutionary War and was technically a lose for the colonists. It did, however, show the British Army that the colonists had fight in them and would actually be a worthy opponent. This is also the same battle where it is purported that Colonel Prescott said, "don't shoot until you see the whites of their eyes!" 

We had the good luck of coming right when a demonstration of shooting a musket was about to start. It was the very last one of the day and the last one of the year. We got a realistic idea of how long it takes to load and shoot the musket and how easy it is to misfire (which can be due to a host of reasons). It was really cool to see but also make you realize just how difficult and crazy it was to fight in this war. This was a great and informative stop on the Freedom Trail!

It was a steep climb up the stairs going up.  In the end, however, it was worth it to get a view of the surrounding.  I also think it is a great tribute to those who fought for our independence (even though that wasn't the goal in 1775).  It was a bloody affair that ended in the Americans losing.  Even though they were victorious, the British felt that they had lost because of the high casualties they suffered.  A great place overall.

Great monument on the site of very important battle. There are awesome views from the top,  but be aware there isn’t any elevator - you should climb the stairs. Very friendly rangers downstairs are ready to provide any information.

This is worth visiting, especially if you've committed to part of the Freedom Trail. I loved walking the neighborhoods and having a summit at the end of the journey. It felt like a great conclusion. 
I would recommend visiting this place, even without the trail. It only takes a short time to walk around the monument and visit the museum across the street. It puts history in perspective when you can see these places. Plus, it's very pretty.
This is a very nice monument. You can climb to the top for free. It is 294 steps to the top but well worth the view! The stairs are spiraling against the outside wall of the inside and well lit.
Climb was a lot of fun.  Did it with kids 5-12. Rangers were very knowledgeable and friendly. Great views of city

name: New England Holocaust Memorial
reviews: Located right off of the Freedom Trail and within steps of Fanieul Hall, the New England Holocaust Memorial is both striking and moving.  It is an immersive experience in that you can read quotes and a short history and timeline of the Holocaust, and then physically enter the towering transparent memorial itself, each tower inscribed with identification numbers representing the multitudes murdered in each of the six death camps, as a foggy mist rises up all around you.  In the midst of the bustling city on a beautify spring day, this was an opportunity for quiet reflection, and an important teaching moment for our young son.  Seeing the numbers rising up multiple stories above our heads in each of the six towers gave a quantification that I don't think can really be appreciated when you simply hear the words "six million".  Seeing six million identification numbers, rising up far above your head and surrounding you, provides a visualization of the amount of devastation and human loss that mere numeric statement can't possibly offer.

This memorial is very tasteful and pays a beautiful tribute to one of humanity's darkest hours. For those who know little about the holocaust there is good education and for those who are familiar with it the memorial reminds the terrible cost the Jewish race paid at the hands of a madman.

This is a free memorial on the street.The glass towers have numbers of holocaust victims etched into them.The numbers go all the way to the top and sides.Each tower represents an individual concentration camp.Difficult to not feel the sense of tragedy and loss.

I think I walked by this memorial at least 3 times before I realized it was a memorial. At first, I thought it was a cool exhibit built into a small park. It's very pretty, modern, and interesting.
It's actually profound. I'm glad I pulled up things to see in the area, and I realized what it represented. I recommend walking through it.

This is a must visit memorial in Boston, it was carefully designed and you can feel the pain for all the people suffered during this historic age.
Should visit as this is also free.

This is a very thought provoking and powerful memorial. Take time to read the words of the survivors, as some are truly touching. There is no entry fee and it’s just off Quincy Market so not far to walk.
This made me cry, but I think everyone should visit here and Ly respect to all those souls who were robbed. Bless them all... go ... read... respect
Came upon this by accident.We read through the inscriptions and were very moved, then we saw all the numbers etched on each panel relating to every person, how very very sad, yet a wonderful tribute.

name: Arnold Arboretum
reviews: I have visited Arnold Arboretum in every season and it is always such a wonderful experience! There are various sections within the park that showcase trees from around the world:  evergreen trees, swampy area with rushes, magnolias, lilac hill that always blooms around Mother's Day, trees from Asia and cork trees from Portugal, linden trees and climbers, hill with birches and bonsai collection, maples and oaks, beech trees - one can explore and always be surprised by something new! The park is a part of Emerald Necklace and is a continuation of green belt around Jamaica Pond and Muddy River. There are several entrances to the park with limited parking, in season there are several portable restrooms and water fountains throughout the park. Dogs are welcome. Hunnewell Building hosts Visitors Center with some education displays and staff to answer questions, share maps etc. This is a trip not to be missed when in Boston.

During Week #1 of vacation with a friend from the South Shore of Massachusetts, we took a daytrip to Arnold Arboretum.  It had been on my wish list of places to go in the Boston suburbs for quite awhile after I moved away from that area.  

The arboretum is the second largest park in Boston’s Emerald Necklace.   

Frederick Law Olmsted designed the 280+ acre park which has about 15,000 trees, shrubs and plants.

We got a driving permit from the office at the Hunnewell Visitor Center as I have one tricky knee, and my friend has had two knee replacements that haven’t helped much.  With the permit, we were able to visit most of the arboretum and were able to get out of the car and walk a bit here and there. 

Our visit was in mid-June.  We were surprised at the number of trees and shrubs in bloom at that time

We found the variety of trees and shrubs from various countries to be very interesting as we’d never seen about half of what the arboretum had even though we’d been to many famous gardens throughout the US.  

Even with the aid of an SUV, it took us over 3 hours to get around to see everything.  This could easily be a whole day affair for those who plan to walk the arboretum.  Picnicking is allowed.     

Our favorite areas included the Bradley Rosaceous Collection, the Mountain Laurels section on Hemlock Hill Road, and the Rhododendrons on the Rhododendron Path.
 
We really enjoyed our visit and plan to return during a different season to see other trees and shrubs in bloom.  

Parking near the entrance close to the Hunnewell Visitor Center is limited.  There are a couple of handicapped parking spaces and about five others.

We rate the Arnold Arboretum at 5.0.   We highly recommend a visit.
 
If you found this review helpful, please click THANK below.

Our favorite open space in Boston is the Arnold Arboretum.  There are lots of beautiful trails, and an incredible variety of trees and plants to enjoy throughout the good weather months of the year.  The special celebration known as Lilac Sunday (usually on Mother's Day) is a fabulous take; so many varieties of lilacs to enjoy, and the scent is wonderful.  One thing about that day, though: don't even think about trying to park nearby.  Take an Uber.
It is a very beautiful park especially for foliage. While it is nearby downtown you still can got chance to find parking slot on weekend. I pretty enjoyed walking around there.

I have visited Arnold Arboretum in every season and it is always such a wonderful experience! There are various sections within the park that showcase trees from around the world:  evergreen trees, swampy area with rushes, magnolias, lilac hill that always blooms around Mother's Day, trees from Asia and cork trees from Portugal, linden trees and climbers, hill with birches and bonsai collection, maples and oaks, beech trees - one can explore and always be surprised by something new! The park is a part of Emerald Necklace and is a continuation of green belt around Jamaica Pond and Muddy River. There are several entrances to the park with limited parking, in season there are several portable restrooms and water fountains throughout the park. Dogs are welcome. Hunnewell Building hosts Visitors Center with some education displays and staff to answer questions, share maps etc. This is a trip not to be missed when in Boston.

An amazing place to visit- such a beautifully tended garden. You can spend all day walking the paths and seeing flora from around the world. It is ike a trip to different climates and continents. Beautiful place for a walk, an picnic, a nap, a dog walk.

It's an easy walk from Forest Hills T stop to reach one of the side entrances to the arboretum. There are plenty of walk to take, make sure to head to the visitor center to grab a map and plan your walk. It's a great contrast to the buzz of the city - worth it for a quiet afternoon.
Great place, great trees, and great fun. That about sums up my experience. I had a blast. Everyone should visit.

name: Charles River Esplanade
reviews: The Esplanade comes alive in the spring, summer and fall with free concerts for families and couples, and the Fourth of July fireworks can easily be seen from this location. Bring your blanket and a picnic basket, and you are in for an old fashioned great time here.
The Charles River Esplanade is great for running, walking, or just taking it in.  Nicely laid out for a various run lengths.

Along the magnificent Charles River, by Community Boating, in downtown Boston, hear the great Boston Pops, or attend the 4th of July Fireworks, or take a stroll or jog in any season, this is quintessential Boston.

We've been to the Charles River Esplanade many times.  The 4th of July Concert is a must if your visiting Boston.  Bring plenty of sunscreen - bring your lunch and blanket and enjoy the concert and fireworks.  Be sure and take public transit, no parking at the Esplanade.

This is my favorite place in Boston! It's pretty, beautiful, peaceful and still right in the middle of civilization where you can hear the cars swooshing in the background. It is a must visit, either during sunset or late in the night.

This is a really nice park, right along the Charles. You can walk (or run) for miles with no interruptions or breaks. Just watch out for the bikes which may come up behind you rather suddenly. Perfect place to stretch your legs, and easily accessible from Back Bay or the Cambridge side of the river.

A little way off the hustle and bustle of the city, Charles River Esplanade flatters the senses of the visitors by its beauty of greens, the sparkle of the river surface, the sound of the birds as well as the smell of the wind. I think this is one of the best spots if you'd like a moment to relax during a tour in Boston.
i saw the river while driving through the city...quite a calm place with birds flying around...people jogging and boats in the river
We visited in winter and although cold it was beautiful. well worth visiting. Lots of photo opportunities

I visit Boston frequently, and every time I am there I run and/or walk on the Esplanade. The river is beautiful, and the path is always full of people especially when the weather is nice. In the summer, there are always lots boats on the river and crew teams rowing. A must do when in Boston!

do the whole Charles River Basin- walk the Esplanade and see the joggers, roller blades, performers, Pops, go across any one of the bridges to the Cambridge side and walk back on the Memorial Drive Side, part the Museum of Science (with a stop at Cheesecake Factory?).
